wikipedia_page.main: Thomas Somers-Cocks (5 February 1815 – 30 August 1899) was a British Conservative Party politician and a banker. He was a founding member of the Canterbury Association.

link_mentions.page: List of MPs elected in the 1852 United Kingdom general election

response: He married, in October 1802, Margaretta Sarah, daughter of Thomas Somers-Cocks, the well-known banker, and niece of Charles Somers-Cocks, 3rd Earl Somers.

The mountain's Māori name, Te Kiekie, refers to a chief who arrived on the Āraiteuru canoe. The European name was given by the surveyor of the Canterbury Association, Captain Joseph Thomas, and recorded on his 1849 map of Canterbury. Like most names assigned by Thomas, it commemorates a member of the Canterbury Association, in this case the banker and MP Thomas Somers-Cocks (1815–1899).
